title: Assessment & Accreditation of OER Learners

author: Rory McGreal, UNESCO Chair on Open Educational Resources (OER)

segmentation: I'm talking today about assessment and accreditation of.
Or we are learners and by coincidence open practice the.
ICDE Journal Open Journal has published.
This is a paper today, so if any of you are looking for more detail you can refer directly to the paper and I can also refer you to a report published by the Commonwealth of Learning.
So our.

Project is about mapping existing projects on assessment and accreditation, analyzing and evaluating scalable approaches to assessment and accreditation, documenting the lessons learned, and proposing some conceptual frameworks.

Assessment is the engine which drives student learning.

For the enjoyment of learning, they're looking at accreditation and assessing whether or not the student knows what you think he should.
He or she should know is what drives our educational system.

Where when you learn something they own what you learn.

From Coursera and what it means really is that their certificates are useless.

But what we do is if a student thinks they know something and they've taken different types of courses informally on their own, or maybe in the workplace, they create a portfolio.
We assess the portfolio and we give them credit for it.
And this is done by.
Quite a few other universities, but it isn't as widespread as it should be.
And in at Athabasca University we actually have a course called creating a portfolio.
So you get credit for creating your portfolio and we teach you how to create a portfolio.
And once your portfolio has been created, we look at it and we give you more credit depending on.
What you have in there?
But the problem with the recognition of prior learning is.
That there's no, there's no standard.

It's sort of done individually by each institution, and it can be quite idiosyncratic, not only at each institution, but within an institution that, depending on who you get a valuating your portfolio.
There can be a wide difference in the amount of credit they would give you for it.
And this creates unnecessary duplication and it's very labor intensive, so it's not a very cost effective way of evaluating student learning.
Now credit transfer.
Is another approach to assessment and accreditation.
And in North America it's fairly easy.

1/3 of our students.

There's different learning scenarios.

Institution, so all kinds of support services that you could pay for, and this may very well reduce the sustainability of full service institutions.

So we.
We need to ask ourselves this question.
Do we need and can we afford the full the full bundle of services that we give at traditional universities?
This gives much more freedom for learners.
They can enroll and complete courses at the institutions of their choice.
And they can pick and choose.
They can change institutions as they strive to complete a program.
They to transfer credits among institutions both within countries and internationally.

Affordability in the future may be the first requirement.
Not an afterthought.
The race may not be to the swift, but to the cheap.
His.
The institutions that can provide good quality assessment and credentialing services at a lower cost may very well be winners in the race.
